content.description: This is the clear walkoff for the rest of the problems, but it has some good slab moves if you go from the ground up.
content.location: It is on the northwest side of the boulder. This is the clear path up the boulder.

content.description: Start on the northwest corner at a low, obvious horn/jug tucked in between the boulder and a low rock. Traverse right along sharp jugs/slopers/pinchers. Climb hard moves to pull up and over just to the left of the tree.
content.protection: A few pads plus a spotter.
content.location: This is on the West face and ascends the northwest arete. The topout is mossy but workable. The moves are thoughtful and sharp, and it could probably be put together in a few different variations. We thought pulling the lip moves was the the crux. Be mindful of the rock to the north/west.

climbs.name: Tweedle Dee
climbs.fa: Ben Moren (But, I'm sure someone has done this before me)

content.description:
Tweedle Dee is a super short, SDS problem:

Sit start, and use the obvious, large holds on the right crack system. Find a decent foot if you can! Pull to the jug on the right arete, and work your way to the top.
content.location:
This is on the vertical-faced, small boulder just below the main B-Lot Boulder. It's a bit closer to the road. The small boulder is on the Southwest side, underneath

Trestle

and

Vasquez Cirque

problems.
In the center of the southern face, this ascends the clear, left-angling crack/seam.

content.description: Start with your left hand on the low undercling and your right hand on the upper, right-angling sidepull. Move to the jug at the lip, and follow crimps, quartz knobs to the left angling jug at the top. A spotter could be helpful as falling too far backwards could lead to a tumble down the hill.
content.protection: A pad or two plus a spotter.
content.location: It is on the West face to the right of the tree.

climbs.name: South Face Low Traverse (right to left)

content.description: Start on the right side of the south face, and work left. Â Your feet are never more than a foot or so off the ground. Finish at the tree on the far left. This is super thin and balancy.
Start using slabby feet and the left-angling pocket. Work up on good holds to the very top. This is a great warm-up.
content.location: On the South face, this begins with a clear, left-angling hold with good low feet.

content.description: Start low in the northeast overhang. Do a stiff couple of moves to pull the lip, and then it's jugs to the top.
content.location: It ascends the Northeast corner overhang.

climbs.name: Looking Glass
climbs.fa: Ben Moren (but I'm sure someone has done this before me)

content.description:
Looking Glass is a short, SDS problem:

Sit start using 2 of the 3 predominant crimps on the left side of the boulder as starting holds. Pull up to the triangular pocket, then work your way up and right of the top.
content.location:
This is on the vertical-faced, small boulder just below the main B-Lot Boulder. It's a bit closer to the road. The small boulder is on the Southwest side, underneath

Trestle

and

Vasquez Cirque

problems.

content.description:
This is the SDS to

Trestle

. It has hard moves down low to get over the lip.
content.protection: A pad or two plus a spotter.
content.location:
On the West face between the trees, start as low as possible in the undercling, and move up to the start of

Trestle

.

content.description: A slabby start leads to good holds.
content.location:
This is on the South face jus to the right of the southwest arete and just to the left of

Turnpike

.
